snippet: The Supreme Court seems poised to allow government workers to refuse to pay for collective bargaining, while denying shareholders a comparable right to refuse to pay for corporate political speech.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column holds that Supreme Court case Friedrichs v California Teachers Assn could widen free-speech gap between unions and corporations if justices allow government workers to refuse to support unions’ collective bargaining activities; ponders whether shareholders should also receive opt-out right.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court seems poised to allow government workers to refuse to pay for collective bargaining, while denying shareholders a comparable right to refuse to pay for corporate political speech.

headline.print_headline: Union Case Points to Gap in the Right to Free Speech
headline.main: Case Could Widen Free-Speech Gap Between Unions and Corporations
